Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Story:
I stood on the sidewalk, my laptop bag slung over my shoulder, mind racing with calculations for the prototype I needed to finish by tomorrow. My phone buzzed with another email from the project manager—stakeholders were pushing for a demo, and I was the only engineer left in the office who could pull it off. My heart pounded with the pressure, every minute away from my desk felt like a setback.

Then I saw my stepbrother, Ben, at the curb, headphones in, about to step into the street without looking. Instinctively, I reached out, but my mind screamed about the time I was losing. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe—Mom had asked me to keep an eye on him after school. But the prototype was everything right now; if I missed this deadline, the whole project could collapse.

I hesitated, torn between shouting his name and sprinting back to my laptop. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, and for a moment, I couldn’t move at all.
